content: Did y'all hear that?
Yes.
Officially being recorded. You might get a pop up that asks you to consent to be recorded.
It just asked me if I wanted to leave the meeting.

Please don't leave the meeting. That's a rude way to ask. So, welcome to this conversation of Cortico's Local Voices Network. Thanks for agreeing to participate. We've begun the recordings so I need to share a little information as we begin. There are three main purposes of this conversation. First, to create a new space for us to listen and learn about each other's lives. Second, we want to connect across groups and in this case geographies to build relationships or to continue relationships we've already built. And third, we want to create a unique listening channel to lift up the voices and needs of the community, our local communities, to media candidates and local policymakers.

So we're inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing personal stories of our [lift] experience as you might be aware, rather than our positions on issues. So we're doing that to help build connections and foster conversations that can deepen our understanding of one another and what's happening in the nation. So the conversation is being recorded, transcribed, and added to this growing collection of similar conversations. As a participant in the conversation, you're providing consent to Cortico, the operator of the Local Voices Network to use the recording in accordance with its mission of fostering conversations in communities and the media, that can improve our understanding of each other. We'll be making the recordings available to Journalists, public officials, researchers, and other participants and partners in the project at Cortico's discretion with the goal of eventually making them accessible to the general public.

So this is a public conversation, and portions of it may appear in a local newspaper or website or be broadcast on a local radio station or appear elsewhere, including other forms of media. So please share only what you're comfortable with being heard by the general public. If you understand and agree to this, please say I agree. And I need you to just unmute yourselves and individually go around and say, I agree. So I'm going to start with David because he's un-muted.
I agree.
I agree.
I agree.
I agree.
I agree.
And Jon, did we hear from you? I need you to unmute.
I agree.

Awesome. Thanks. So we want to make sure everyone gets a chance both to share and learn from others in the conversation. To support those goals, we have a few guidelines. These will sound very familiar to you. First, speak for yourself and out of your own experiences, allow others to speak for themselves. Share the time, allow others to finish speaking and take turns. Stay curious, ask honest questions, pause, take time for reflection, listen generously, assume good intentions while acknowledging that even well-intended comments can have negative impact. Silence all devices including cell phones and smart watches, or just mute yourself. Is everyone okay with these guidelines?
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.

So for the ease of this virtual conversation, we're going to use a modified circle process where each person will take a turn. And I'm going to post the order for people to respond in the chat box, so that we can just keep track of who's going and what order we're going to go in. Jennifer, Peter. I spelled your name wrong, David.
It's fine.
It's one of the easier ones.
Just don't call me late for dinner, that's all that matters to me.

All right, sorry about that. So I'll help transition us from one person to the next in case there's any need for timekeeping, but we'll just keep going in this order. So first, actually I should have asked this first. You also could use a pseudonym should you choose to, and we can still change that if you prefer. You could put your pseudonym where you see the name at the bottom of your picture, you can rename yourself and we can use that as we continue the conversation should you choose to. Anybody want to do that? All good with names. The other thing I want to mention that wasn't in my rundown is that we upload the audio, but we discard the video. So the video is really just here for us to be able to see each other and have a more natural conversation. But there's nothing that's done with your image after the conversation, it's just the audio that we upload.

So first, we'll just go around. I know you all know each other's names, but we'll share our names and then a little bit about a value that brings you to this conversation. What made you say yes when I posted on Facebook and made the invitation? For the first round, I'll start. I'm Parisa. And one of the things that is really more and more important to me, but especially important to me right now is human connection. And you all were among the first folks I thought of when we knew that we needed to move to Zoom because I've missed you. So staying connected matters a lot to me. Jon.

I'm Jon. And one of the things that intrigued me and made me want to do this was Gun Group was so great, and although we have vastly differing opinions on a lot of different subjects, I think every one of you is genuinely a very good person.
Jennifer.
Did she get frozen?
She looks frozen. Yeah.
There we go.
Here you are.
Yeah. I think two things that bring me to this group, one is trust. And how long has it been? Two years now?
Mm-hmm (affirmative).
Almost exactly.

Yeah. So we've had two years to I think build trust among ourselves. I mean, Jen, I'm really proud of you for putting on your sneakers and getting your clipboard out and getting yourself elected. Maybe it wasn't vocal enough while you were running, but I was really proud to know you that you did that, and went out and won. And John and I have had a couple of conversations about child rearing when I was in despair of an incident I had with my son, I mean complete despair. John came to my rescue and settled my nerves and known my views about guns and things like that really helpful with the other members of the group on this and that. What makes success, she paints a picture of herself not doing very well, but she's just doing spectacularly. So I'm really proud of her as a young woman on the rise. But I wanted to share something personal about my Guns Group. And I subsequently wrote about it, about being a victim during the Brett Kavanaugh trial and why I did not come forward for Brett Kavanaugh hearings, and why I did not come forward for 40 years about what happened. The local Cleveland Rape Task Force and they contacted New Orleans and found my case, which had been sitting for 40 years in some dusty warehouse. And now New Orleans police is actively pursuing it 40 years later, there's no statute of limitations it turns out. So I want to thank this group for forcing me to come out of what I had been keeping as some terrible secret for all this time and actually beginning to come to some closure with it. So thank all of you for your support. But in terms of COVID-19 is what we're talking about, right?
Yes.

I think some of my professional instincts have bubbled up, because we do crisis management training. John probably is very familiar with this if he hasn't disappeared. But the military does it a lot, we do crisis management training for many, many things. And I was on the H1N1 task force for our embassy in Serbia and also we were responsible for taking care of the American population, including sheltering in place as one outcome of H1N1 spread, but also keeping a track of what was happening in Serbia and Serbia's response. And so I'm really frustrated in my own local environment because I feel like my own local leaders, not Ohio necessarily, and I won't even get into the federal level, but on my local level where people are in their houses, they don't know what's going on.

I've been really trying to break free from local authorities, some type of communications effort where if you do something like this and talk to people, even if it's only online. And so I feel like my instincts of crisis management are put out, but I have nothing to do with them because I'm nothing and nobody in this town and nobody listens to me, it's like, there she goes again. So very frustrating that I feel like I've got some expertise, but there's nothing I can do with that.
Thanks Jennifer. We're going to get more into COVID specific questions too, so we'll dig a little deeper. I'll just return us to just name and value that brought you to the conversation with Peter.

Well, I think that I took a long, long break from Facebook and I just came back onto Facebook, I don't know, maybe three, four weeks ago give or take. And when this jumped up I thought, Oh, well maybe coming back onto Facebook was a value because it's been awhile since I've seen any of these folks and it is a memory that I cherish of the time that we spent, and frankly I hadn't seen my buddy Jon in a while. I was getting ready to send him an email anyway, so I thought, why not? This is probably a good way to reconnect.
Thanks Peter. Deza'Rae.

Yes, Deza'Rae. And I decided to join because similar to those who spoke before me, I really cherish and valued our time together in D C and online. And to think that there's an opportunity for that again, I wanted to jump on that because my conversations with most of the people in this group are still very different from the conversations I have with people at work or at the university, even if we have different opinions. There was just something that's missing from them that's in all of you. And I think it comes to that, that trust and being open to opinions and values or perspectives that are different from your own.
Thanks Deza'Rae. Jen.

Hi everybody. Jen. I would say for me it's connection. I have been out and about a lot as an elected official, but I've also been going back for my teaching certificate and substitute teaching, and so I have become accustomed to talking to tons of people every day. And now it's just my husband and my two kids, and I love them dearly. But I'm excited to connect and talk to other people.
Thanks Jen. David.

David here. The values that brought me to this conversation was the opportunity to reconnect with you all face to face. I tried to stay in contact with most of y'all on Facebook, either through the written word or private message or interactions in the comments on something that I may post or that you may post. And first of all, congratulations Jen on getting elected to the school board. Next step the governor's office. Right? So it was just curiosity to catch up with people and curiosity to check out this new form of technology, because some of you may not know that I did start my own Alabama news and media site at the beginning of the year. So this is something that I was definitely interested in as a journalist to see what it's all about and maybe take advantage of it to write some more in depth stories as I continue to grow.

Because right now it's just me, but the plan is to add more staffs through college interns and people that want to get into journalism and have a platform to write. But as we continue to grow the staff and the readership, this may be something that I may be interested in and utilizing going forward.
Thanks David. Did we hear from everyone that round?
Yes.

Okay, great. So I know that, so this is a special group because we usually have folks who may not have known each other before gathering and you clearly have some basis. But since it has been a while, our opening question is around a story from your background that can help the rest of the group understand something about you and maybe especially what informed some of your concerns or experience around COVID-19. It doesn't necessarily have to be a direct link, but it's just a story that can help us understand what makes you tick, that's totally fine too, regardless of its relationship with the COVID-19 topic. So take a moment to think of just a story that you could tell in a minute or two that can help us get a little better understanding of you. Jon, are you ready to start?

Oh, absolutely. Again, Jon here. I think my background most of you already know, but I was in the military for 20 years and then I was a police officer for 20 years, and at the county, the state and, and the federal level. And now that I'm retired, I reflect back on that a lot. I had the misfortune or fortune, however you want to look at it. I guess experience wise, it was fortunate that it was misfortunate to have to go through it to work a couple of cases that involved home invasions. And that was when I was in Central US, and they were pretty brutal and they left an impact on my life. I got a call the other day from the VA, they were wanting to survey veterans and take up some opinions about PTSD, and I said I don't think I have PTSD.

And she pursued it a little further and said, "Well do you have anything in your life that stays with you?" And I said, yeah, when I pulled up 18 month old child from the ground that was thrown from a car and was dead, that was pretty brutal. But I think about every day the home invasion cases I worked on. So hence, we're now in this with the COVID-19 virus and it's well on my mind, I feel very prepared because I've always taken my own safety because of my background to heart. And I think I and some others urged that when we had the Gun Group, I respect everybody's decision whether they want or don't want to have a firearm. But I guess, and I don't mean to be doom and gloom, but it concerns me that we're only about this far from services breaking down and then society breaking down. I pray it doesn't come to that, but I've already heard rumors about thefting on the rise and vandalism increase. And so I hope it doesn't come to that, but that's what COVID-19 has been on my mind about lately. I'm done.
Thanks John. Jennifer.

Yeah. Somehow okay. I think I already said in the opening that having led a task force for the state department, and having received meaning for that task force, I'm in a bit of despair locally from my town about preparedness and also attitudes. And I guess I don't want to talk about the national level, in our state level Ohio, it's pretty well publicized now. But I think there's a real role at the local level for politicians and police officers and others that are members of the board of education for example, coming forward to make an effort to communicate with people what's going on. And I think we're not used to doing that, we're not used to being in a crisis situation and having to make those communications. So I've been trying to gently nudge, our elected officials not to send out memos every day or settle, but do something like this or something on Facebook so that you can connect with the people that elected you and be more informative.

Because what happens to the national level or the Ohio level, I'm from this town called Solon. It seems still so distant from us. We have in Ohio 400 cases, and of those the majority of them are in my County. And I just stopped hearing anything from my officials other than wash your hands and physical distancing. So I'm a little bit in despair of local officials, they're not seized with the urgency of this. And if they're not seized with the urgency, it's hard to tell people to stay off the streets and not go do those things.
Thanks Jennifer. Deza'Rae it's nice to see your face. Peter.
So I thought I'd expose myself.

I've been thinking a lot lately, especially as I listened to governor Cuomo and our local County executive talk on a daily basis about supply, and about not being able to get the basic supplies that they need to keep the first responders and the medical people safe. Not being able to get the ventilators that we're going to need, that the other hospital based supplies, hospital beds, you name it, that we're going to need. And it reminds me of a job that I had in the late nineties at Carrier that was all about supply chain. And my job was to optimize the supply chain, getting products from our factories to our customers in the quickest and most efficient way possible.

And while the factories were here in the US, it was doable we could achieve the goals that we needed to achieve. But the company was engaged in a massive effort to outsource, if not to Mexico, then to China. And I wrote memo after memo, email after email, report after report, talking about how, while this might seem wise from a cost perspective, it would save labor dollars. It was very unwise from a supply chain, and it's curial perspective. And Oh, by the way.

Supply chain and a security perspective, and oh, by the way, it probably really wasn't any cheaper when you factor in transportation cost. I was told over and over again how wrong I was and how it was all going to be fine, and it's not fine. I was thinking this morning after listening to the governor talk again about ventilators and about factories being converted over, and there are at least three factories that used to be in the carrier network that could be making ventilators tomorrow if they were still open and if they were asked to do it. It wouldn't be a tough transition for any of them, but guess what? Those factories are all closed.

That work is all being done in China, some of it in Mexico, and one of those factories is one of the ones that our president talked about saving when he was either still a candidate or right after, and how really sad and tragic that is that we are going to pay the price for doing what seemed like the best idea, I guess, for the executives at the time but is now going to have real, real world ramifications. Think about what would have happened in 1940 if all of our heavy industrial manufacturing had been outsourced and we wouldn't have been able to ramp up to prepare for World War II with our supply, the military goods we needed then. This is the same thing, and here we are again.
Thank you, Peter. Deza'Rae?

I think for me, there's a couple things. It's obviously a public health concern that people don't think that they are carriers for the virus or that they can't get it because they're young or they're not sick, but they're also putting the vulnerable at risk, but it also seems that the whole COVID thing is getting very political, and it isn't necessarily ... We're not really focusing on public health and getting everybody tested and helping people stay healthy. It's kind of like people who are getting tested are mostly like employees or people who can pay $5,000 for the test, and it seems that like all the politicians that are getting involved, and it doesn't really seem like the focus is on necessarily public health when it's a public health matter.

I don't know if because it's happening at election time, that it's a coincidence, but similar to what John mentioned earlier, crime rates are going up. Jails and prisons are releasing people from jail early to decrease the population in these facilities. They're not, like in Oregon, they're not arresting people for low level crimes, which may be something that's they should necessarily been doing in the past, but knowing that, people feel a little more free to do whatever they want, and that's not good. So, it seems like there's multiple things going on, and we need to more take like a holistic view at it and not just one track mind or one pathway because there's many different factors in play.
Thanks, Deza'Rae. Jen?

So, yeah. I would say that something that has been coming up for me a lot is I spent a lot of my adult life living on the Susquehanna River, which is a very large river that goes through several States but through all of Pennsylvania, and so I have, before, like I've been evacuated from a place where I lived. The town I lived in actually had like a small Island in the river, and so that would flood, and we'd all get evacuated. So, I feel like I lived before through times when everyone around me, we all had to hit pause, take care of ourselves, take care of our houses, and we wouldn't have mail for a couple of days, and so things just weren't necessarily working the way you are used to them, but we were always in our own little bubble. There was always an outside world not very far away where things were still working, and you could still go for help and go for supplies.

So, two Thursdays ago, our governor came out and said, " Hey, everybody. How about we just not get together in groups larger than a hundred?" but he didn't say anything about schools, and so every parent in the state said, "Wait, there's more than a hundred kids in my kid's school, so what does that mean?" I think we all started freaking out because we had some information but not enough. I took this trip to Costco, and I swear I had a panic attack, and it was like I've never had one before. There was no chicken like at all. There's no toilet paper, that sort of thing. I was out of chicken. I just happened to be out of it, but they had a couple like full chickens. I had to buy like a whole chicken. I thought, I grew up hunting. I know how to butcher this chicken. I'll be okay. I was all like, "Oh, my God. Oh, my God."

I thought to myself, this is a problem, and there's no outside world to go to where it's safe and where it's okay. We're all going to experience this. It just made my world feel like it was very small, and I keep thinking about that. I keep thinking about, oh, if I need this, can I just go ... Oh, no, I can't. Never mind. So, that is what's been hitting me a lot.
David?

What Jen just said reminded me of a meme that's been going around in my area about everybody now knows what it feels like to go through a hurricane, which is the one of the two life stories I'm going to combine real quickly to illustrate how I feel about this. Several years ago, the Southeast was hit by a massive snow and ice storm, and I don't know if y'all remember this, but Atlanta shut down, Birmingham shut down. Atlanta looked like The Walking Dead where the people were getting out of their cars and walking home off the interstate because they couldn't go anywhere. They were frozen in place.

Then, I also hearken back to Hurricane Ivan, which was the big hurricane before Katrina. Ivan actually hit down here in Coastal Alabama, but yeah, we've been through many hurricanes down here, so we know how to prepare. We know how to do all that stuff, but we have a saying down here, Hurricanes, if it's below a three, it's just a reason to party. If it's a three, it's time to start paying attention. For me, we're at class hurricane three, which means it's time to pay attention, be ready, get your supplies ready. Nobody else outside of coastal areas really knows how to prepare for those types of things. We do it every year. We get, go pre-buy what we can buy that's going to last, shelf-stable food, that kind of stuff. Then, we just go get the necessities when a storm comes, but nobody else knows how to do that, so they're all reacting the way Birmingham and Atlanta did when they got that big snow and ice storm because Birmingham and Atlanta don't get big ice and snow storms frequently, so nobody knew how to react, so that's what I'm kind of seeing. That's how I relate what's going on right now, is with those two events.

Thanks. I don't know about anyone else but I'm just feeling the weight of all that's been shared, the sort of emotional significance as well as the worries based on concrete experiences folks have had from other trying times, to put it very mildly, but I just want to acknowledge that there's a weight to that that we're all carrying. I think carrying each other's perspectives also add ... It's helpful to say your thing, but also, it adds a weight to carry that, so just want to acknowledge that. I'm wondering about, so several of you shared some part of a response to this. So, I'm just going to go a little deeper into it, so that I guess maybe that wait observation is a preface as well, but we want to move into some conversations about your hopes and concerns during this time of pandemic. I have a few questions to start us off, but then we can kind of go a little more freeform after we've gone through the first couple of questions.

So, I'm going to start though with a hope question, which is just, what are some of the things that have given you hope since your community started responding to COVID-19? If you could share a story from your experience that helps illustrate that, that'd be great. I'm going to have us go in the same order for this question and the next, and then we'll go freeform. So, let's start again with Jon.

Okay. Well, I'd like to sound optimistic, but I'm not real optimistic about the way people, my perception of how people are reacting to it. I don't think young people are taking it serious enough, but I guess, what I do see positive that gives me hope is that overall, I think people are coming together. I guess, for a while this weekend, politicians came together. They seem to have separated now. They're setting a poor example for that, but I don't want to get political. I just think it's wrong especially when we all need some resolution, so does the stock market.

I do think people in general, I see a lot of people that ... Facebook is my obvious big connection to the world now as it is maybe for most of you. I'm not a Twitter guy, but I do see people that are talking more and listening to other people. I think that's a little better now than it was. I'm hoping so, anyway. That's really about all I can say about it though.
Thanks. I'll just share the question in case folks need a refresher as we go around too. Jennifer?

Hi. Okay. I don't know why it lags on me. Probably you want to hear me. But I have a hope. I'm on home quarantine with my 17-year-old son, and the last couple of years have been dismal from his point of view. He's a 17-year-old. Very difficult from my point of view. So, I have this hope that he'll have this memory of the two of us in this house having to rely on each other, entertaining each other, and maybe chatting a little bit more likely than we had before. You'll not automatically go into screaming matches about stupid stuff.

So, my hope is that this will become a memory for me and my son of how we bonded together and helped each other and developed a greater appreciation for each other. I see no evidence of that happening on his part at all. It's just strictly hope right now. The reality is I can't get him out of bed. I can't get him to do much of anything, but I think there's a part of his brain that knows that I'm all he's got right now, and vice versa. He's all I've got. So, I hope that eventually, this will turn into that type of pleasant memory.

I just moved back to this place where I was born five years ago, and I moved back into an area where there's already pretty entrenched relationships especially for people my age, with people that have known each other their entire lives. I kind of come in here with all my background and da, da, da, run for mayor, do all this snazzy stuff. I'm really impressed by the friendships that I've been able to develop, and I think that this pandemic that we're in right now has helped me and my circle of friends that I've come to know really appreciate each other, appreciate our similarities, appreciate our differences, and appreciate that we're there for each other.

We're going to do a Zoom of my little tennis club on Wednesday, and most of the ladies who play are in their 60s and 70s, so they're all vulnerable. Their kids have moved away, and now, they're like, "Oh, I'm going to download that. Help me figure out how it works." They're obviously kind of excited about having something to do with being able to get together at their regular time than what we normally play tennis and still socialize a bit. I thought that was nice that we were there for each other. The friendships really came to the fore.
Thanks, Jennifer. Peter?

Well, I'm a little bit like John here because I'm not feeling it yet that everything's going to be okay. I live across the street from one of the largest grocery stores in the Syracuse area, and the last time I was in was about a week and a half ago, and it was a zoo. That's a kind term and an insult to zoos. People were being positively cruel to each other, pushing, shoving, grabbing the last of ... For what? I'm still a little unclear what people are going to do with 487 rolls of toilet paper and 18 gallons of milk that's all going to go bad before they can possibly consume it. I'm just hoping that the madness passes sooner rather than later and that people can start being more concerned about each other than about themselves because if they keep this up, I think, John, I think you're right. I think we get to the brink of systematic breakdown.

I guess my glimmers of hope come from my county executive for whom I had no time until about three weeks ago who's seeming to step up to the plate. I don't know who's given him advice, but whoever it is, he's doing a good job. I'm hopeful for the governor who not too many people like, but as a number of people have said, all of his worst qualities that people hated the most are serving him and us well in this crisis. He did a great conference this morning and actually did make me feel a little better about how we were going to get to the other side, but boy, I keep thinking ... I remember back in the days when I was little, and I would see the pictures of the kids in iron lungs from polio, and I just feel like it's coming back that way. Well, one of these days, I'm hoping that something's going to ... Sky's going to open up, and I'm going to get a ray of sunshine. It's going to make me feel better.
Thanks, Peter. Desiree?

I'm kind of 50/50 on the optimism too. I feel like a lot of systems in society are breaking down right now, and we are trying to keep it together, but we don't have a lot of means to do that right now because of the pandemic. I feel like the breaking down is forcing us to have these relationships with people that we might have disconnected with or haven't socialized with as much because of work or other life things that were distracting us, which is good, but I'm mostly worried about people who might be going homeless or losing their jobs.

I guess I'm thankful that they're trying to keep research going. I mean I'm, right now, the only one in my household who has a job, so I'm thankful, optimistic that the governor isn't allowing evictions in the State of Oregon, those kinds of things, kind of things that society was behind on already for people who don't have a lot of resources or security. It's kind of like we seem a little late. It's happening because of this really bad experience when people were already kind of experiencing these things. So, it's confusing for me with a mix of the good and the bad right now.
Thanks, Deza'Rae. Jen?

So, while this is all crazy, I feel like my community is responding really well to it, and just to give you guys a little bit of background, this year, by the end of November, the incidents of flu in Pennsylvania was up 1, 000%. The epicenter of it was here in Western PA, and it went through my son's school. I joked that the elementary schools are just infectious disease wards, like at this point, I mean they're just gross, so my whole family had the croup go through in November, and then we all got the flu in December. So, a lot of people had just been sick and like laid out.

A dear friend of mine who lives here in town, her niece who's 20, two weeks ago, was in Disney for spring break. Last week, she was in the hospital. They did test her. She has not received the results yet, but they also said to her, "Well, you just have pneumonia and like the fact that a 20-year-old is hospitalized for pneumonia is kind of par for the course this winter." They didn't even necessarily think it meant she had COVID. They just tested her because she had traveled because she had been in Disney.

So, I know I've seen in some other areas of the country, they are like truthers about this, who don't think it's real. It's the flip side. Around me, people were like, "Have we just had this the whole time?" It's just been so bad. So, some of the stuff that we're doing, like in the local town Facebook groups, St. Patrick's Day, it was print out a shamrock and put it in your window so that when people walk around with their kids, they can play like scavenger hunt, right? Writing messages on driveways. We have a local gym teacher who he and his family are making videos teaching you how to do a dance, and they're putting them out every day, and it's a way to get you moving.

So, it just seems like we're doing some creative things to try to stay connected, oh, and putting Christmas lights back up. I don't know if you guys are doing that. People are putting their Christmas lights back up, or for some people, just turning them on again because they never actually got to take them down. So, I don't want to say like everything's fine here with with what's going on, but it just seem to me that it's forcing us to do some creative things to stay connected. So, that feels good.
Thanks, Jen. David?

My hope out of all this is that we as a society and we as individuals and we as a government understand or come to understand the importance of preventative and maintenance health. I know the healthcare, health insurance, Medicare for all has been a big topic in this presidential election cycle. I don't ... Yeah, I'm not trying to get political here, but I think a lot of people from a lot of different political points of view can agree that getting your annual physical, getting your annual exams and your checkups depending on your age and your family history is important.
